p: As expected, prior to influenza intranasal infection, the consumption of L. paracasei did not induce any significant changes on weight, temperature and appearance of mice ( S1 Fig). Moreover, no histological differences were evidenced in the lungs prior to the influenza infection ( S2A Fig). After infection with influenza virus, infected control mice rapidly lost body weight ( Fig 1B) and body temperature ( Fig 1C) and developed pathological appearance ( Fig 1D). The analysis of viral load by RT-PCR revealed that L. paracasei-fed mice had lower influenza loads after 3, 7 and 10 days of viral infection ( Fig 1E and S2B Fig). Moreover, fewer hemorrhagic lesions were observed in the lungs of L. paracasei-fed mice compared with the control group, 7 days after influenza infection ( Fig 1F and S2C Fig). Collectively, these results suggest that consumption of L. paracasei, initiated before influenza infection was associated with better health status in mice.
